item.description:
Objective: learn as much as possible about edible mushrooms, toadstools - recognize them safely
 - acting by turns -
different games are possible:
Quizmaster (changing) shows image to next player; if answer correct (name/classification...) card may kept
 - simultaniously -
Quizmaster (changing) shows image to all players; very first (correct) answer takes the card

In the 19th Century, Medical Schools needed Cadavers to further their knowledge but there weren’t that many available. This is where you come in. Your job is to dig up graves to provide the Medical schools with enough body parts so they can continue their research. But it isn’t that easy, the police are trying to stop you and of course you have to be careful because there are more than just dead bodies in the graveyard.

Grave Robber is a fun family game for 2 - 4 players where players try and dig up and sell body parts with the aim of making the most money. Each player takes the role of a grave robber (body snatcher) and on their turn they roll two dice and move both their piece to try to dig up/sell body parts and a Police figure to try and hinder/arrest other players. You can visit the Tavern to get help in the form of Tavern Cards and there's a choice of two medical schools - one pays a little more if you're lucky. The church is their in case of trouble with the monsters.

An unusual idea, a dice and cards game that has no dice or cards. All the required options are built into the plastic box. You 'roll' the in-built dice and that will result in you 'drawing' cards, which are displayed in the many 'windows', so you know which cards you have.

Using this strange contraption, the publisher says you can play all sorts of card games and in the box the rules for Blackjack and Poker are included.
1100 trivial and educational quiz questions. Via a 6 sided die players determin the category and question they have to answer.

A quiz game. There's a deck of cards with 1/6 of a map. On the reverse side are questions. With a die you determine which question you have to answer. Winner is the first to gather all six parts of the map.
Monopoly with Fortuba Düsseldorf, the famous soccer team from Germany. All the traditional elements of rolling, moving, purchasing, earning, and spending.
Monopoly with Hamburger SV, a famous soccer team from Germany. All the traditional elements of rolling, moving, purchasing, earning, and spending.

name.value: Monopoly: Vom Niederrhein ins Bergische Land

item.description:
A monopoly (from Greek monos μÏŒνος (alone or single) + polein πωλεá¿–ν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements from Nordrhein-Westfalen, in Germany.

“Nothing cannot exist forever.” - Stephen Hawking

After the Big Bang, things moved quickly. So do you. Players in the game of Eons take on the roles of universal architects competing to shape the universe on a cosmic scale by gathering elemental building blocks to create stars, planets, and other cosmic phenomenon. In a strategy game like no other, the architects engage the laws of the cosmos, using stars to forge more complex elements and form other heavenly bodies.

In EONS, players must spend their own essence to marshal these elements, carefully gauging their resources and the benefits received from their planets and stars, as they guide the formation of their cosmos eon after eon; working to achieve the most victory points through a variety of strategies and hidden agendas to achieve their version of the universe. Because eventually, the universe will end, and only one player will be victorious...

Players build stars using elements commonly found in the universe, Hydrogen, Carbon, Oxygen and Iron. Once they build stars, the stars perform fusion, and can produce resources for the player to use to build additional stars, planets or other cosmic events. Each cosmic body the player builds is worth Essence, representing the power and influence the Architect has in the universe, and that Essence can be used to purchase more elements from the elemental stockpile to build more items. Players can also destroy stars and collect resources from the dead stars, and this is where the game turns to strategy and planning. Every cosmic body that is destroyed will decrease the entropy countdown, and when it reaches 0, the game is over.

Remaining cosmic bodies that grant victory points are totaled, and the player with the most victory points, wins! Although the goal is to have the most victory points at the end of the game, you will find that the game is also a resource management game, as if you deny resources that stars need to undergo fusion, they will die and accelerate endgame. Be prepared, build judiciously and destroy when you must to defend your universe!

In Cradle: Creator's Challenge, you are a Creator. In the name of competition, you and your rival will conjure a world unlike any ever before conceived. Sweeping plains, rugged mountains and deep oceans spring into existence at your command, twisting and crashing into your rival's lands in a colossal battle of will. Then—by your grace—the world will be filled with life; be it by brawn or brain, your creations will vie for dominance. Fanged monstrosities, indomitable swordsmen, educated scholars, suave traders... Anything you can imagine, you may create; the Challenge will support their method of battle with a single system of resolution.

The Challenge is between two Creators, each with uniform tools at their disposal. Play is divided into two Phases: In Phase I, Creators alternate playing Tiled Cards to create a map, and use octagonal Origin Points to set where their Creations spawn from. In Phase II, Body & Soul Cards are paired together to make 3 Creations per team. After their Creator describes them, pawns are placed on the map to represent them. As pawns are moved around the map, they will come into conflict with Rival Creations. Conflict is resolved by rolling 1 to 3 six-sided dice. A continually exchanged Event Card assigned to each Creation provides aid or presents challenges as the game unfolds, typically by modifying the number of dice rolled.

By rolling successfully, Creations will lose Heart. When Heart is reduced to zero, the Creations is removed from the map. Origin Points have no Heart and are removed from the map when rolled against successfully, but are much harder to succeed against. The game is over when one side has lost both Origin Points or all 3 Creations. That side loses.

Soccer Card Game is a two player card game, each player will have his players with their own abilities in a representative 52 card deck.

The players will have to manage their hand, and place the players in the field, according with the ability of each player so they can move the ball toward the goal. But...the defensive player will have to work on making it hard for the attacker... One way or another the ball will move!

Finish your deck to end the first half, go for a second round for a full game...

Quick to learn, easy to play, a fast and blast of a game! ;)

-- V3 --
A WHAT CAN BE GAME:

In this V3 of Soccer Flow, i added Tactic Cards, that allow coaches to choose the starting tactic and add some special cards to the team deck.
I also add the Special cards, that allow the game to be more unpredictable as a soccer game should be!
Now each player, will have a different number depending on each position they will play, allowing the teams to be more competitive, and each coach has to choose wisely the players for the team deck!
Each player will have a combination of 0 to 3 special abilities, and a star number that indicates the max. number of cards of that player that can be in the team deck.
So coachs will have to choose 10 players +1 Goalkeeper, and the sum of the star numbers of each team will difer, as so the number of actions each team can do in the game!

In real soccer, my team is always best than any other!

You're a team of lowly maintenance robots built to keep the space station operational and clean so that the colonists can get on with...whatever it is they do. Unfortunately, the station has been invaded by creeps, alien creatures that slowly advance toward food (the colonists) so that they can multiply. The only thing keeping the colonists from being completely wiped out is your knowledge of the station, a couple of specialty tools and abilities unique to each of you, and a little bit of problem-solving code installed so you could do your jobs efficiently.

Jupiter Rescue is a co-operative strategy game in which players work together to escort 28 colonists to an escape pod before they're converted into alien creeps. Each turn, players may take five actions, choosing from common options — moving themselves, moving nearby colonists, or killing alien creeps — and a series of programming cards that grant them special abilities. These cards can be played on the player's turn to activate the ability. Each player also gets to choose one card to be his "core" ability, letting him use it every turn instead of discarding it.

New creeps are added to the board, which is composed of tiles, at the end of each player's turn by rolling a die; if a tile fills up with creeps, it's destroyed and removed from the game. Players lose if enough colonists get turned into creeps, or if certain key board tiles are all destroyed. Double-sided tiles allow for hundreds of station variations.

item.description:
What does local politicians really do? Try to be a part of the municipal council. Learn to prioritize and distribute resources - both according to political affiliation and for the common good.

In the last round an opinion poll will be undertaken - the winner of that also wins the game.

At the start of the game you randomly choose one of six different political characters (from six different, fictional, political parties [Alfa, Beta, Kappa, Delta, Sigma and Gamma]).

Each political character has one issue that he or she must fight for and another three issues that they must prioritize in the game. These issues are: “school”, “leisure”, “local transports”, “culture”, “business”, “social services”, “elderly care”, “waste management”, “welfare”, “housing”, “water & sewer”, “fire & rescue”.

As elected you spend resources (chits) on one or more of these areas that you are assigned. But look out! The next player has another set of issues that they must fight for – and they will grab every opportunity to take resources from your areas and put on their own.

The best way to try to win is to get the other players on your side, to contest and argue. There is no successful “sneak under the radar”-strategy in this game. Loud and vocal and on the attack but smart, is a winning strategy. But that is not enough; sooner or later you (your issues) will be stripped of resources – and you must be smart when trying to get them back to your most important issues.

During the course of the game you will start one turn, the next player starts the next turn et cetera (that means if you are more than four players, one or more will not get to start a turn). Each player gets the same amount of new resources, but not the same opportunity to shift resources from issue to issue, that is decided by the dice.

There is another random factor in the game, a deck of event cards that is used once at the end of each turn.

The ultimate goal of the game is to win the “opinion poll” at the end of the last turn, year four (one election cycle in Sweden). The opinion poll is won by the player that has collected most resources; double points for each resource on one’s issues at heart and one point on the other issues that you fight for!

There are also rules for winning the overall game – not only do you compete against the other players, you all must successfully meet the public opinion and you all must collectively have enough points to pass the game. So it is not all about competition, you must also collaborate with your opponents from time to time. And that’s trickier said than done.

Eximo is a member of the Checkers family designed on 1 February 2013.
 
The game has orthogonal and diagonal movement and capture. There are no kings, only men. Men can jump without capturing. When a man reaches the last row, it frees another man.

Eximo is played on a 8x8 square grid. Each player starts with 16 pieces placed in predetermined locations on their side of the board (see image).

OBJECT
Capture all your opponent's pieces by jumping over them, or stalemate the opponent so he has no moves.

TURN
In each turn, a player can make one of the two actions: move or capture.

MOVE
A checker can move in 3 directions: forward or diagonally forward (north, north-east or north-west).

There are two types of moves: ordinary move and jumping move.

- ORDINARY MOVE: a checker moves to a (forward or diagonally forward) adjacent and empty square.
- JUMPING MOVE: a checker jumps over a (forward or diagonally forward) adjacent friendly piece if the next square in the same direction is empty, placing the jumping checker on the next empty square. If the same player's checker can continue moving by jumping another friendly piece then it must do so. During the jumping move that checker cannot capture.

When there is more than one way to jump, the player may choose which piece to jump with, and which jumping option or sequence of jumps to make. The jumping sequence chosen is not required to be the one which maximizes the number of jumps; however, a player must make all available jumps in the sequence chosen.

CAPTURE
A checker can capture in 5 directions: forward, diagonally forward, right or left (north, north-east, north-west, east or west).

- CAPTURE: a checker jumps over a (forward, diagonally forward, right or left) adjacent opponent's piece if the next square in the same direction is empty, placing the jumping checker on the next empty square. The opponent's piece is removed from the board immediately. If the same player's checker can continue capturing by jumping another opponent's piece then it must do so. Capturing is mandatory, and you must keep capturing as long as it is possible.

As in the jumping move, the player chooses freely which jumping sequence to take.

ON THE LAST ROW
When a checker reaches the other end of the board, it is removed from the board immediately and the player gets two extra-moves to make instantly: dropping two new checkers in any empty square in his own first two rows, except in the four squares on the sides.
(The drop zone for Black: b1, c1, d1, e1, f1, g1, b2, c2, d2, e2, f2, g2; for White: b8, c8, d8, e8, f8, g8, b7, c7, d7, e7, f7, g7).

If a checker reaches the other end of the board and there isn't any empty square in the drop zone, the player loses that piece. If there is just one empty square in the drop zone, the player gets only one drop.

item.description:
Takeaway is a simple card based game for 2 - 6 players where the object of the game is to make money by serving as many customers and or making deliveries while the take away is open.

Game play is simple - The game is played over 15 rounds. Each player has 1 turn per round. On your turn you get to perform TWO actions from the following list in any order. They can be the same action twice or two different actions.
1. Pick up two Menu Item Cards
2. Pick up one Delivery card
3. Serve one Customer

Deliveries are worth more but the menu items are unknown to the player when they take the card.

At the end of each round move the clock one space along the time track.

Once the time token has been moved to 02.00 then all players have one more turn then the game ends. The game will also end if there are no more customers left to serve – if this is the case then all players get to finish off the round.

The winner is the player whose orders add up to the greatest value.

1650: A capa & espada, is a miniatures game that takes place in the Kingdom of Iberia, a ucronía very similar to the Spanish Empire in the seventeenth century, which is being besieged by multiple enemies. The Court flee southward to new capital called Ysbilia. But the Old Purple Regiment, with the Duke of Alba at the head, expelled years ago as traitors Ysbilia return, taking its main points and autoploclamando the "New Order", ready to take over the crumbling empire, to resurface and acaudillar the reconquest. Any man willing to fight now travels to Ysbilia ready to deliver his weapon on either side in search of maravedis.

The game allows us to represent skirmishes between gangs of the two main factions, the Old Regime and the New Order, in different scenarios (Degollinas, ambushes, escort missions, assaults, etc ...) and with conditions as varied nightly contests, meteorological phenomena, rules enclaves (scenery that provides special rules who take their control), antagonists (characters managed "the game" and will face either the cause) and even an option to play solo when you will always contenders to that challenge.


1650: A capa y espada, es un juego de miniaturas que se desarrolla en el Reino de Iberia, una ucronía muy semejante al Imperio Español del siglo XVII, que esta siendo asediado por múltiples enemigos. La Corte huye hacia el Sur, a la nueva capital llamada Ysbilia. Pero el regimiento de los Morados Viejos, con el Duque del Alba a la cabeza, expulsados años atrás como traidores, regresan a Ysbilia, tomando sus puntos principales y autoploclamando el “Nuevo Orden”, dispuestos a tomar las riendas del derruido imperio, para resurgir y acaudillar la reconquista. Todo hombre dispuesto a luchar viaja ahora hacia Ysbilia presto a ofrecer su arma en uno u otro bando en busca de maravedíes.

El juego nos permite representar escaramuzas entre cuadrillas de los dos bandos principales, el Antiguo Régimen y el Nuevo Orden, en diferentes escenarios (Degollinas, Emboscadas, misiones de escolta, Asaltos, etc...) y con condicionantes muy variados como contiendas nocturnas, fenómenos metereológicos, reglas de Enclaves (escenografía que otorga reglas especiales a quien tome su control), Antagonistas (personajes manejados "por el juego" y que se enfrentarán a cualquiera que los provoque) e incluso una opción para jugar en solitario cuando te falten contendientes a los que retar.

item.description: Get Blue is a kinetic, magnetic table-top game comprising of tiles and discs. A Starter Set has four tiles and five discs. Tiles have a magnet inside. Discs have a metal core. Players score points by spinning their discs, connecting to and knocking over a tile. If a disc connects to but does not knock over a tile, players loose points. The Red Tiles are worth one point. The Blue Tile is worth two points. The Flame Spinner is a double point disc. (Points are doubled if you capture or are reversed captured.)

Goodnight Moon 123 is a numbers game for children based on the Goodnight Moon book by Margaret Wise Brown with illustrations by Clement Hurd. The rules offer seven variations of play for children at different levels of skill and experience. Ultimately, this is a matching and identification game. Each number has a written number tile, with some text, and a sister tile with a number of illustrations that match its number.

According to the publisher, this game encourages listening, matching, and beginning number and reading skills.

Contents: 12 sturdy, interlocking matching tile pairs, rules for play, and notes for caregivers about games and skills

Reading is not required to play.

In Nada!, you want to claim as many matching dice as possible – until no matching dice remain, that is, at which point you can yell "Nada!" to claim what's left.

In each round, you start by taking six white dice and six orange dice, with each die having six different symbols on it. Someone rolls all the dice in the center of the table, then players race to be the first to yell out a symbol that is on at least one white and one orange die. If correct, the player collects all the dice showing this symbol; if not, the player collects nothing and sits out the next turn. Once a player has claimed dice, this player rerolls all the remaining dice. If no match can be found, the first player to yell "Nada!" and cover the dice with her hand claims all the remaining dice. Players tally their scores – one point for each die collected – then play another round. Whoever has the highest score after three rounds wins!

Nada! includes variant rules for two other games. In one, the players use all 36 dice at once, playing as above but most likely scoring more points each time since more dice will be in play. The round ends after all dice of one color have been claimed, and the player who collects the most dice wins.

In the other variant, players start the game by secretly drawing 8, 12 or 16 dice from the bag (with the number based on the number of players). On a turn, each player chooses 2-4 dice from his stock, then all players roll their dice simultaneously, claiming dice as explained above. The players take back any unclaimed dice, then choose 2-4 dice again for the next turn. Once a player has no more dice in hand, the game ends, and the player who has collected the most dice wins.

item.description: In Dicht dran, there are cards from 1-100. Each players has 8 cards. Each round there is a target card (e.g. 60) and a gap (e.g. 11-46). Everyone plays one card, face down, then cards are revealed. If you are the closest to the target card, you'll earn positive points. If you are not the closest, but your number fits in the gap, you get rid of negative points. If you can't do both, you have to draw new cards. The round ends as soon as one player has played his last card.

item.description:
Game based on a British television show, but here geared down in difficulty of the questions so that 8 to 12 year olds can play.

Played over a 20-hex game board, two teams (one having one more teammate than the other) compete to answer questions with the initials given (What BE is Noddy's friend? Answer - Big Ears. That hex then belongs to the side with the correct answer. The first team to connect top-to-bottom or side-to-side wins the game.

A dinosaur-themed memory game.

The 49 dino cards (7 different species in 7 different colours) and 7 T. rex cards are shuffled. Nine of them are placed face-down in a 3 x 3 grid to form the "dino hide". The remaining cards form the draw deck. The T. rex token is placed at the center of the table.

Before the game starts, the 9 cards in the dino hide are turned face-up and players try to remember them. Then they are turned face-down again. 
The start player takes the top card from the draw deck. The dino from this card is the one he/she has to find in the dino hide. He/she turns over a card from the dino hide. 
- If it is the same colour or same species as the one on the search card, the player wins that card and puts the search card in its place, face down. Then he/she gets two more tries. A player's turn ends when he/she has either won three cards or turned over a card that doesn't match the search card.
- If a player turns over an incorrect card, his/her turn ends immediately. The search card still takes the other card's place in the hide, but the original card is removed from the game.
Then the next player's turn starts, and he/she takes a new search card from the draw pile.

When a player has won three dino cards, the T. rex gets wind of the dino meeting. The T. rex token is placed in front of that player. It stays there until another player collects three cards and T. rex runs over there, or until a T. rex card is revealed. If a T. rex card is revealed (either from the draw deck or the dino hide), the T. rex chases away one dino owned by the player that the T. rex token is currently at. That player loses one of his/her cards, but also gets to put the T. rex token into the center of the table.
The player who has revealed the T. rex card gets to takes the card. It counts the same as any other card.

The game ends when the draw deck has been exhausted. The player with the most cards wins the game.

The racing game Poomp! uses simultaneous speed card play to represent the time aspect of racing.

Playing a card exactly within the window for moving ahead may mean waiting a split second for the right opportunity. Pushing ahead with a card too high or too low will require that you burn certain additional cards in a different window, causing you to waste seconds a different way.

As a speed game with modeless play, Poomp! is inherently not friendly to new players who are playing with experienced players. Practiced players should ease new players into the game by (1) taking things easy on new players until they internalize the (few, but essential) rules for card play, and by (2) gradually introducing the full ruleset (powerups, additional numbered cards, character abilities) to new players in a manner similar to that described in the rulebook.

Although Poomp! plays up to 8 players, fewer players can race together: The game AI simulates missing players.

Playing Poomp! requires the following components:

• Track cards depicting straight, curved, or tightly curved track
• Terrain cards depicting shouldered or unshouldered, railed or unrailed terrain
• Powerup cards of varying types
• Powerup markers in three colors
• Car markers in different colors
• Several decks, numbered 1 to 10, in different colors

Poomp! is set in the post-apocalyptic setting of New Amarillo, a setting shared with South Quarter Independent’s upcoming games Radio Cloud (SQI012, a roletaking game), Bragging Rights (SQI016, a storytelling game), and Dustbowl (SQI027, a wheeled combat game).

A witchcraft-themed memory game for children.

The 25 cards are printed on both side. One side shows one of five magic objects (elixir, charm, magic hat, spell book, owl) on a white background. The other side shows one of five hiding places (bed, grandfather clock, chest, tripod, fire place) on a coloured background. There is one card for each magic object/background combination.

The cards are laid out on the table, with the coloured hiding place side facing up. The start player rolls the two dice. One die shows what object the players are trying to find. The other specifies what hiding places they players may search to find that object (i.e. if one die shows the owl and the other the bed, the players are allowed to turn over the bed cards to find the owl). If the active player manages to turn over the correct card, he/she gets to take the card and rolls the dice again. His/her turn ends when he/she turns over a wrong card.
The sixth side of the dice is a joker - the lucky player gets to choose the magic object, hiding place, or both (if he/she rolls the joker on both dice).

If a player rolls a combination that has already been found and he/she remembers, he/she gets to steal it from that player.

The game ends when all five cards of one type of hiding place have been claimed. The player with the highest number of cards wins the game.

Wild West Exodus is a tactical skirmish game set in an alternate Wild West timeline - branching off from real-life history after the American Civil War in the 1880s. It is played with 35mm miniatures and uses a system that relies on rolling 10-sided dice to determine results. Players adopt a faction (such as Union, outlaws, and native Americans) and build their forces with a pool of points dependent on the scenario played. A mechanic of the game allows players to use Influence tokens (generated by their forces) to re-roll dice. The game's objectives are dependent on the scenario played and can include killing off all your opponents' forces or having the largest force (in terms of cost) at the end of 6 turns.

name.value: Tide of Valor: The Normandy Campaign

item.description:
Hit the beaches of France in the first phase of the Allied assault on Fortress Europe. As either Bradley or Montgomery you match wits with Rommel, The Desert Fox, and the best the Werhmacht has to offer.

Winning the battle of the beaches is just the first step. Whoever gains the upper hand in this fight will set the stage for the next sector.

The British mission is straight forward, capture the city of Caen, a strategic center surrounded by flat rolling fields; perfect tank country for their burgeoning armored might. But the Germans wrote the book on armored warfare. With some of the best SS Panzer divisions moving into Normandy the Germans will have the Panthers and Tigers necessary to crush the Tommies and drive them back into the Sea.

The American objective is the farming town of St. Lo, but to reach it they must overcome a different set of nightmares. Miles of the harshest defensive terrain in Europe stands before the GI's. Bocage, hellish constructs of impenetrable earth and rock provide the perfect cover for Panzer Grenadiers lying in ambush.

The tide of battle will surge and ebb but only one side can claim victory in Normandy!

What would you call a horror film about an evil booger? A sci-fi about a gangsta lunch lady? A romantic comedy about a clumsy proctologist?

In Schmovie, you're trying to convince others that you have the best title ever for whatever concept is being pitched to the producers. What's the actual storyline? Doesn't matter – the title is what's important, so put your all into making something memorable!

Each round, you'll roll the genre die (which has sci-fi, rom-com, horror, action, drama and producer's choice), then draw two premise cards, one What? and one Who?. The combination of those three items gives you the concept for the movie. Now you just need to come up with a title. Do a good job, and you'll win a schquid trophy; collect enough trophies, and you'll win the game.

item.description:
GEEK DICE (Dice games) adds Lizard and Spock to the classic game of Rock-Paper-Scissors for an incredibly fun and geeky experience. Players can try to calculate or analyze all they want, but GEEK DICE comes down to chance... and some old fashioned luck!


 Each player receives 1 die and an equal number of chips
 Each player antes up 1 chip at the beginning of each round
 All players roll the dice simultaneously
 Consult the chart to see if there is a clear winner or draw
 When a draw occurs the players involved continue rolling off
 Losers are eliminated until the next round
 The winner is allowed a chance to roll the Atom to claim the pot. If the pot is not won it continues to grow
 A new round begins
 The last player with chips wins the game

item.description: Equilispace is a dexterity game. The main feature of this game is a plastic disc, with an hemispheric base (on which it oscillates). On the upper side of the disc there are twenty cavities (11 holes and 9 furrows). Players alternate in putting a glass marble into a cavity, trying to avoid a serious imbalance of the disc. The player whose move causes some marbles to roll off the disc, is out of the game.

Jakub WÄ™drowycz - FKGK is a polish collectible card game for 1 or more players based on Andrzej Pipiluk bestselling novels.

Starter pack contains:
- 1 Hero card
- 6 Enemy cards
- 6 Places cards

Starter packs are random. There are also 9 cards and 20 cards booster packs.

Game is easy to learn. Every player has a Hero card in front of him and 3 card piles. First with Places, second with Enemies and third with other cards (called Fresh Pile). Each Hero has four stats - Strength, Power, Protection and Glory. At the beginning of each turn player draws 5 cards from Fresh Pile. In second phase player is drawing one card from Enemies pile and one from Places pile. Hero will fight with this Enemy at this Place using Power or Strength depends of the Enemy type. In third phase player can boost his Hero stats with cards from his hand. He can also play Jobs cards, which gives extra Glory points if are fullfiled. At the end player is rolling the dice for his Hero and for the Enemy and sum up with proper Hero attribute against same attribute of the Enemy. If Hero result is better then player get Glory points described on the Enemy card. If not HEro is losing all Items he was using in current fight and enemy stays on the table. 
After 12 runds for each player game ends. PLayer with most of the Glory points wins the game.

Zombicide Season 2: Prison Outbreak takes the players to an indoor environment with vicious close-ranged fights, Prison Outbreak contains all the needed material for a new player to enter the Zombicide universe, and lots of content, almost all new, for an existing Zombicide player to expand his game experience. In fact, Prison Outbreak holds even more material than the core game published in 2012 (now nicknamed Season 1)!

The Prison Outbreak will feature berserker zombies. They’re really tied to each other. Prison tiles display tortuous alleys, small rooms and doors everywhere, filled with berserker zombies immune to ranged weapons. You have to think fast, foresee the improbable and jump into melee at every turn. This is like a modern dungeon where levers are replaced with switches to open or lock doors, use security rooms and reach secret areas.

Prison Outbreak also contains six new survivors with their Zombivor aspects. These survivors are really designed to act as a team, as their skills really complement each other. They’re precious assets to any Zombicide team.

Missions featured in the rulebook form a campaign on their own, as survivors battle to turn a zombie-filled prison into a reliable shelter. Many challenges await them, but they have new tools of the trade: riot shields, automatic shotguns, concrete saws and many more toys. There’s even an alternate ending.

item.description:
How to play
Begin the game by having every player roll a die to see who goes first. The person who rolls highest goes first, followed by the person to their left and so on and so forth. Should two or more people roll the highest number than they must roll off until someone has rolled higher.

When it is your turn you must do the following.
1. Draw a card from the draw pile.
2. Use a power card, place a character card in play, or use a character card power.
3. Discard cards from your hand until you have only five left.

Power Cards
Most power cards may only be used on your turn. When you play a power card you immediately do whatever it says, then discard it. Well… not immediately, but before you do anything else game related. So you could eat a sandwich or something.

Some power cards may be used at other times, which is indicated on the card itself. When in doubt, the card is right.

Character Cards
Character cards may be placed in front of you during your turn instead of using a power card or a character power. Place the character card in front of you and leave it there until something tells you to place it someplace else. This is now considered to be an “in play” character card. You may not use the Character Card Power the turn you place a character card in play. You may only have three character cards in play at a time. If you place a fourth you must discard one.

Character Card Powers
Instead of placing a character card or using a power card you may use the power on one of your “in play” character cards. This power works just like a power card, except you do not need to discard the character card to use it.

Note, some character cards have passive effects that do not require you to use them on your turn. These abilities are always in effect and should be easy to determine. If an argument does ensue the following characters have “passive” abilities.

Khan-El, Biel-Tel, Beorn, Penelope, Neil and Harris.

How to Win
This is the part you have all been waiting for isn’t it? To win the game all you have to do is have all of your in play character cards be the same characters as on your Dream Team card. Once you do that you win!

Card game published as a promotion for UNESCO. The tile means 'The Unesco Rainbow'.

The cards feature the letters U N E S C or O. There are eight of each letter and, in the main, they have different coloured backgrounds.

Each player, in turn, may lay a card on the table, that can legally go next to another card. There are none at the start so a U must be placed. After that, you may lay an N next to the U. You can place the N alongside the U or beneath it. The next player may now play a legal letter next to any card on the table. Thus, the word UNESCO will be spelt many times perhaps, horizentally or vertically. Think of it as a UNESCO crossword. If you cannot play a card, you draw one from the stock.

The first player to use all their cards wins the round. The other players total the value of cards left in their hands and take a score for them. Colour matches can matter because this makes a more penal score. After an agreed number of rounds, the player with the lowest score wins.

Blankity-Blank! is a word game that will appeal to anyone who likes Scrabble, Boggle, Scattergories, and other word games. It's a family game designed for 2 to 6 players ages 12 and older.

To begin a round of Blankity-Blank!, you take a card from the box and let all the players see it. On the front of the card is an incomplete word with some letters left blank; for example, P--N-. You and every other player have three minutes to write down all the words you can think of that would complete that pattern, like phone or piano or plant or prank. When time is up you all read your lists aloud and cross out any word that more than one person wrote; you score points only for words that you alone thought of.

The front of the card indicates whether this is a 1-point, 2-point, or 3-point round, according to how many potential matches there are for this pattern. 1-point cards have dozens of possible solutions, 2-pointers not so many, and 3-point cards have the fewest of all. So you score 1, 2, or 3 points for each unique word in your list. (P--N- would be a 2-point card.)

When you've recorded the scores for this round, you may look at the back of the card. It shows a list of the most common words that would be correct solutions, so players can see some of the words no one thought of.

You continue to play with another card and another until one player has scored enough points to win. This can be 25 points, or 50, or any number the group agrees to.

The game includes over 500 cards, a pad of answer sheets, and a timer.

Swish Jr. is a version for children of Swish, a pattern recognition card game in which players make matches – dubbed "Swishes" – before opponents.

Swish Jr. includes 42 transparent cards; each card has some combination of small shapes on it, with these items coming in four colors. To set up the game, lay out 12 cards on the table. Players simultaneously try to create "Swishes" by spotting two or more cards that can be laid on top of one another in some manner so that shapes of the same color fit. Create a Swish, and you claim the cards used, with new cards then being laid out. Whoever claims the most cards wins the game.

In WordAround players try to discover and read words written in round cards before their opponents. The players who gueses it correctly gets the card as a point. Whoever has more cards at the end of the game wins.
The game includes 100 cards with 300 words.

item.description: Child Beauty Pageant Tycoon is a game where you and your friends take the role of a mother whose greatest goal in life is to have her children win Beauty Pageants. The first player to win five Beauty Pageant crowns wins the game. There are 4 very different ways to make your Child ready to compete in a Pageant. 1) Spending a night with a Stud to give your child an edge from the very start. 2) Gaining experience by simply competing in Pageants. 3) Training your Child in a special Skill. 4) Buying a special 1-use Item to be used in any Pageant. Each Pageant will have different entry fees and winnings, and they will focus on different stats. When a pageant focuses on a stat, it counts for double towards winning the pageant. For example, let's say Mary Beth has a 'Smarts' score of 3. In the Pageant shown above, she will get to double her smarts score and it will instead give her 6 points toward winning the Pageant! Glitz or Talent stats still count toward winning, but they aren't doubled in this Pageant.

A unique version of Monopoly based off of the Northern Kentucky town of Fort Thomas. Properties include historical content and prominent places around town. The game is played nearly the same as Monopoly, but with a few variants. There are different cards, and different rules for gaining money in relation to the cards and properties on the board.

Players customize a deck of 30 cards depicting the heroes, villains, Zords, and Megazords of the Power Rangers universe. Cards are found in special starter sets, booster packs, and also packaged with Power Rangers toys from the 2013 line.

Turn Order:

1. Draw 2 cards.
2. Choose a Ranger or Villain to play, or pass. Discard cards equal to the play cost.
2. Optionally, players can summon Zords or Megazords if a Ranger was played in the previous step.
3. If only one player played a card, that card deals damage equal to its damage value twice.
4. If both players played a card, each player performs a "judgement" by rolling a die (or using an app or Morpher toy) to determine what power level their card fights at. The higher Power value wins. The loser is dealt damage equal to the winning card's damage value.
5. If the winner's card's rock/paper/scissors icon defeats the opponent's, the winner deals damage twice.
6. Damage is represented by moving cards from the draw deck into the discard pile.
7. The winner's card is discarded, the loser's is moved to the reinforcements area, where it can boost the "judgement" value in subsequent battles.
8. Play continues until one player runs out of cards in his or her draw deck. That player loses and the opponent wins!

item.description:
Critical Mass is a fast-paced mech combat game. Players go head-to-head in this fighting-strategy game with deck-building aspects. Players choose their favorite mech to battle it out, with each mech offering a different loadout of cards to start the game and unique powers.

Each turn, players play a card face-down. When both players have chosen a card, they reveal them. Cards resolve based on their speed if they haven't been interrupted. Weapons deal damage and interrupt the enemy, while defending avoids weapon hits. Upgrading offers you additional cards to add to your arsenal but is vulnerable to being interrupted. Lastly, recharge reloads spent cards.

As cards are played, they go to their owner's cool-down pile, where they remain until they're reloaded. As players take damage, the armor on their mech is destroyed. When enough armor is destroyed, an armor core becomes vulnerable and can be destroyed to stun that mech for the next turn. The game ends when a mech's armor is completely destroyed down to the last core.

item.description:
This is a game for children with an American Civil War military theme published in 1890.

Players begin the game as a drummer boy and attempt to rise through the ranks and become a general. The board is styled like a maze and players move based on the results of a spinner.
Certain spaces on the board have special rules. A drum symbol allows the player to spin again. Other spaces have instructions like "Surly. Go to Guard House" and penalize the player.

The first child to reach the "General" space is declared he winner.

Includes a colorful 13" x 13" board illustrated with Civil War scenes, metal tokens, and a drum-shaped spinner.

Game designed by creative team Lans Macabre. It's an area control strategy based on resource use, betting and bluffing. Players take the roles of megacorporations’ CEOs to enlarge influence and dominance of the world. To do so they must spend resources to get control of cyberpunk freelancers - but it's not as easy as it sounds. The cyberpunks are very hard to control and everyone will try to recruit them. Each player will bet on different resources to get best results.
Future INC. is all about getting control over locations and gathering resources.
Each player starts with the same amount of skyscrapers and tries to expand by building new and capturing or destroying those belonging to other players. Thanks to skyscrapers players gain control over locations – areas of the cyberpunk world - and gather resources.

There are five types of resources in the game:
Credits - represent financial capabilities - used to build new skyscrapers.
Cybernetics - represent technological advancement - used to change ownership of enemy skyscrapers to yours.
Gear - represents military potential - used to destroy skyscrapers.
Programs- represent defense against "cyber terrorism" - used to counter enemy actions.
Influence - represents political power and intel – used to gain an advantage by manipulating game’s mechanics.

The most important thing in Future INC. is using free mercenaries - known as Cyberpunks - to do the dirty work. Using resources, corporation may influence a group of Cyberpunks to capture enemy building and gain victory points.

Game is divided into five turns, each has three phases:
1st phase, collecting resources: in which players gather resources, determine new targets for Cyberpunks and update points status.
2nd phase, mission: in which players, using bluff, bet on resources to gain control over the Cyberpunks.
3rd phase, actions of corporations: in which players spend resources to perform actions against each other.
Points are gathered by winning control over Cyberpunks and locations. The player with the highest score at the end of the fifth turn wins the game.

Future INC. High-Tech Stakes is a dynamic strategy for everyone who likes power struggle and a poker-like experience.

By the same designer and publisher of the Judge Dredd Miniatures Game, 2000AD: Rogue Trooper Miniatures Game is a science-fiction skirmish 28mm miniatures wargame based (as the title suggests!) on the Rogue Trooper stories of the classic British comic, 2000AD.

A Kickstarter project started in February 2013, successfully funded within one day of launch, the intention is to publish a hardback rulebook and a range of miniatures for both sides, of the perpetual civil war on Nu-Earth. The Nort and Souther armies are asymmetrical (army lists are featured in the rulebook; units each have a base points cost and upgrades available for additional points).

The scope of the game is intended to be from a handful of miniatures (one GI vs. a Nort squad for example) up to company level actions, including light vehicles.

The range planned for release currently includes:
GI Rogue Trooper
Souther soldier squad set (8 figs)
Nort soldier squad set (8 figs)
Nort elite assault squad set (8 figs)
Nort & Souther officer squad set (6 figs)
Souther lazooker team squad set (6 figs)
Nort snipers and Black Dome sniper squad set (7 figs)
Skorpion Battlewagon (light tank, 3 variants planned)

Troops have their own basic statistics (points cost, movement, defence and armour values, morale (called Will-to-Fight; WtF in this game!), individual abilities (traits) etc. which are then augmented by the range and damage ratings of the weapon with which they are equipped (range, damage, traits). The more powerful a weapon is, the more combat dice rolled.

Rules cover ranged and close combat, remote weapons, indirect fire, elevation, suppression, air units, fighting from and in structures, etc.

Missions can be generated within the 'Engagement' chapter by combining various mission profiles (attack, defend, probe, hold, etc) to give an alternative to simple meeting engagements of equal cost forces. Success or failure is adjudicated by victory points specific to the various missions.

NB: This information is based upon the first release of the draft rulebook, and thus may be subject to change before release.

Objective:
Be the first to reach target space
 - moving by turns -

Typical 'roll and move' game, probbably published ~1920/30's
Roll the die, move forward; ending on a marked space read aloud the datails about that sight-seeing place and follow instructions, printed on a 2-sided rule sheet. Because it was played by adults you have to spend money first before you start. 
Very nice drawings/printing and - of course - pewter pawns

This 1903 card game by L.T. Hodges is played with 65 cards. There are six suits with 10 cards in each, plus 5 "cabbage" or trump cards. Players try to match cards in their hand to those on "the board" (the table). The object of the game is get the greatest number of cards, cabbage cards and fives. The 1904 edition also contains rules for playing Wiggs Auction.

From the box:

All the fun of a music quiz night in your own home.

This chart-topping quiz is packed full of fascinating music trivia questions (both popular and classical) guaranteed to keep everyone entertained. Suitable for all the family and any number of players.

Your knowledge will be pushed to the limits by the following categories: One Hit Wonders; 60s & 70s; 80s & 90s; Albums and Singles; Music Charades; Music & the Movies; General Music Trivia; Pop Music; Name That Tune (on CD).

The [i]Complete Music Quiz Night In[/i] contains everything you need for night after night of fascinating music trivia fun - all you need to supply are the players!

Contents:
50 question cards containing 1,900 questions and answers.
Audio CD for Name That Tune category.
Answer sheets.
Quick start instructions.
4 pencils.

Promotional game for the Dutch bank Raiffeisenbank and this is The Bank Letter Game.

Simple crossword card game, similar to games like Lexicon and Kan-U-Go. In your turn you may play a maximum of 4 cards. Words must be formed that use at least one letter of an existing word (except for the first word obviously which, incidentally, must be a four letter word). Any word can be extended though, if possible. Game includes two Jokers which have an image of an old motor car.

The first player to use all his cards wins the round. The other players total the values of their unused cards and the winner of the round scores a total of all those points (each card has a number value on it).

The winner of the game is the first player to reach a pre-agreed score.

The backs of the cards are quite novel. They can be used to make four different jigsaws. It is suggested that 6 to 8 year olds might like to do the jigsaws. I doubt it, they are extremely difficult for their size.

Line Dice is a simple game of path creation, where 2 to 6 people divide up a pile of 36 dice and attempt to build a path that continues forward for as long as they have pieces to allow it. Players attempt to create a path that makes it impossible for their fellow players to continue, well trying to keep enough playable pieces to avoid being removed from the game prematurely.

A family game based on the Swedish television show with the same name, hosted by Harald Treutiger. The goal of the game is to advance to the final act where you get to see if you got what it takes to win the elusive gold bar. You do this by drawing cards that have all kinds of weird statements on them, put money on if they are either true or false and then roll dice to tell who was right. This is mixed with some contextual statements like for example "will the phone ring during the game session?". Though usually it's mostly a game of plain luck.

The Giraffalaff Limbo will have your preschoolers howling with laughter as they try to limbo alongside the ticklish Giraffalaff giraffe. A quick spin of the wheel reveals which silly animal's walk you'll have to do under the limbo bar--whether it's the bird walk or the crab walk. Just make sure not to knock down Giraffalaff or he'll go into a frenzy of giggles, and you'll be out of the game! Designed for children ages three and up, this limbo set is a fun and activity-filled game that will keep your child engaged.

A swedish game from sometime in the 1960's where you manage a dog kennel. You buy dogs and enter them into competitions in different countries, breed them, sell puppies and try to make your kennel the most valuable of all the players. The game board has one path that everybody has to follow and you spin a wheel to move. Every square you land on says something that alters your situation in some way. Maybe you get to mate your dogs or they get sick. At the end of the trail the player with the most valuable kennel wins the game.

The object of the game is to manage a football team and take it from Division 4 to Division 1. To collect and make up a balanced team of players by buying and selling, and then to win the World Cup.

Playing around the board progressing from Division 4 to Division 1 each manager has the opportunity to win money, buy players and play Leauge Cup games. Finally challenging any other managers to play the Final of The World Cup and win.

Managers move around the board based on the role of the dice. Landing on different squares results in a choice of actions - taking cards, getting bonus payments, taking new players or challenging other managers to games. Managers may buy or sell players at any time throughout the game - with the ability of different players determining the outcome of matches. By winning matches, the managers team is promoted to a higher league and ends the game by achieving a win in the world cup final after reaching division one.

item.description:
Turf Wars is a game of conquest. Players are encouraged to form alliances and manipulate the situation so that ultimately, your faction, and preferably your faction alone, dominates the land.

There are up to ten (10) rounds of game play for Turf Wars each of which consists of five (5) phases: 
• Perform Pre-Event Action(s)
• Place Reinforcement Troops
• Reveal Event
• Select Action Cards and Perform Actions
• Score & Spend Dominance Points

Object of the Game
There are four (4) ways your faction can win:
1. Dominate the appropriate number of turfs on the board that match your faction’s Home Turf.
2. Land the killing blow while wiping out your faction’s nemesis, if in play.
3. Achieve the objective outlined on any of your Secret Win Cards.
4. Attain highest number of Dominance Points (DP)at the end of 10 rounds. This results in a win only if no other win conditions are met first.

This is a Japanese science fiction wargame set in the universe of the Legend of the Galactic Heroes. This set covering the Sirius Campaign, was the early age battles before main story.

Two scenarios are contained in the game, and the fictional space battle that each was drawn in the story is reproduced. These are being called a fleet battle, but when either is said, it is close to the land battle of Napoleonic age.

Each player control one or more star fleets. 
Each fleet is commanded by one admiral, and organized by 10 to 20 ships units.

Each turn, a fleet are activated in the unintentional order by chit-pull system, and it resolves a movement and a combat. 
An average admiral has only one or two chits. But the heroes of the story has four or more chits, and it is activated many times during one turn. 
A battle is resolved with adjacent hex on the Odds CRT.

The winner determined by the number which made a fleet collapse. A fleet collapses when a fixed unit is eliminate or admiral's mental agitation.

item.description:
Cheeky rabbits race around the field, hiding behind bushes to outwit the sharp-eyed fox.

A roll and move, players choose three rabbits of the same colour and place them on one corner of the field on the START hole.

1. The starting player throws the dice and does two things in the following order: 
a)Moves the fox to the sector of the centre circle corresponding to the number,
b)Moves one of his Rabbits in a clockwise direction on the track.

E.G. If a 2 were thrown, the player first moves the Fox onto sector 2; secondly, he moves one of his rabbits two places in a clockwise direction.

2. If the fox can "see" any rabbits in that sector of the board, they must go back to their START hole.

3. If a rabbit is in the same sector as the fox BUT is behind a bush, then it is hidden from view and does not go back to START.

4. Play moves in a clockwise direction.

5. On their first three turns, each player must bring out all three of their rabbits. If a rabbit is sent back to his START hole, it must be brought out onto the track on the player's next turn.

6. Any number of Rabbits may occupy the same space on the track.

7. If a six is thrown the player may have an extra turn.

8. A player does not have to throw the exact number to get a rabbit HOME.

The same rules apply for a two or three player game.

item.description:
Annihilation is a Battleship-style game for two players using pencil and paper. Each player receives an identical printed sheet from a game pad, featuring a circular overhead map of the northern hemisphere. The map is divided into boxes by longitudinal and latitudinal lines, which are labeled by numbers and by names of constellations. Some boxes are shaded, representing the oceans. Also present are boxes to track each player’s hits; in place of ships are (in order of most to least boxes) Capital, Trade and Industry, Air Base, Navy, and Peace. Each player “hides” each of these objectives on his own side of the map, vertically, horizontally, or diagonally. The Navy must be in the ocean, Peace is a single box that may be anywhere, and the rest must be on land.

Each player then takes a turn firing volleys at the other side. A volley consists of 15 bombs, which can be any combination of airplane bombs, rockets, or atomics. Airplane bombs count for 1 bomb against the limit, rockets for 3, atomics for 5. Volleys are done all at once, with the opponent not announcing hits until the volley is over. Players track these developments by crossing off boxes on their paper. When a player sends a volley, if he has previously received any hits, those hits are subtracted from the 15 bombs he may fire on his current turn.

Airplane bombs strike only the square called by the player, rockets strike the first square and any two adjoining squares called immediately by the player, and atomics strike the initial square as well as the four adjoining squares along all four sides. Any target hit on one square by an atomic is immediately destroyed, any target hit by a rocket suffers an additional box hit after what the player targeted. Should any player strike the target of Peace, the game is immediately over, otherwise the game is won when all of a player’s other targets are destroyed.

"Fast-moving championship basketball game by Lowe"

The game is played with two dice; one standard d6, and one with letters:

P (Plus): ball is to be moved directly forward
M (Minus): ball is to be moved directly backwards
R (Right): ball is to be moved to the right
L (Left): ball is to be moved to the left
D (Diagonal): ball to be moved diagonally

The object of the game is to score by moving the playing piece across the court into the basket at the far end. The player who scores the most points within the playing time is the winner.

(Source: instructions)

Guile is a medieval memory card game of deception and intrigue for two players. Players are either the noble King Arthur or the nefarious Sir Mordred, and the Knights of the Round Table are the instruments of your influence in Camelot. Your chosen knights will advance your schemes as you trace the web of subterfuge and manipulate it to your own ends. The victor will wield the most influence when each Knight's loyalties are revealed.

The Round Table is formed by eight face-up Knights, with each player controlling four. Each Knight also bears a face-down Influence Card on top of it. On his turn, a player can look at the Influence Card of his Knight-errant or exchange that card with an Influence Card of any other Knight at the Round Table. Play continues in this manner until the turns have circled the Round Table twice. At that time, all of the face-down Influence cards are revealed, and the player who has the highest sum of Influence wins the round. A new round is set up and played again, and the first person to win two rounds wins the game.

Who will hold sway in Camelot? And who will hold sway on the morrow? Only time will tell...

Guile includes the 'inspansion' "Extended Cast", which adds even more possibilities for treachery and deceit.

item.description:
Each card has both a letter and one face of a standard die. Before each turn, 5 dice are rolled and placed on the dice board in order of their colors. Then the player tries to play a word of 3-5 letters, whose die faces match a contiguous subset of the dice on the board. If they do, they score the sum of the cards' pips, doubled for 4-letter words and tripled for 5-letter words. There are also wild cards, and slug cards that can be added at either end.

The winner is the first person to reach the specified total score, e.g. 100 for 4-5 players.

From the web page:
" Cool Factors:

Easy to carry.
 Quick to learn and play.
 Fun for word-lovers and strategy gamers alike.

Description:
Shuffle the custom deck and deal each player ten cards. Select a card from your hand to keep and pass the rest to your neighbor. Keep cherry-picking a single card from each hand until they're depleted. Each player then tries to make a single word from his cards. Letters you use in your word score points--cards you take but don't use count against you! Be the first to score 100 points, and you've won.

It has a deck of 60 cards, which have a letter and number, in different colors. Rarer letters like J and Q have multipliers on them, and there are wild cards.

From the web site:
" Cool Factors:

Amazing 12+ Games in one!
 Fast, stimulating game play!
 Fun for the whole family - always fresh!

Description:
“Oh My Word” is not just one game, but is 12+ games in one, with more being developed and added frequently! You can play any of the games with the same deck of cards!

One of the most fun and exciting games ever created is “Battle of Words!” It comes in “quick start,” "basic," and "advanced" versions. The basic version can be mastered in a matter of minutes and is fun for the entire family. The play consists of forming words, lengthening existing words, combining words, and stealing words from your opponent(s). The advanced version is easy to learn but will stimulate and challenge even the most astute word gamers. In addition to the basic play, there are 20 action cards that create all kinds of excitement and dynamics between the players. In either version, each player competes for high score through word values, word length values, bonus letter values, bonus word values, other word bonuses, and the number / quality of words acquired by the end of the game.

You can also play the following;
“Cross Words” - plays similar to a crossword puzzle game, without the limits of a regular game.
“Play On Words” - plays similar to a 3-D crossword puzzle game, without standard limitations.
“Finding the Right Words” - plays similar to a cubed word game, without the grid or cube.
“The Last Word” - plays similar to a word jumble or word search, with strategy & scoring options.
“Simple Words” - plays similar to solitaire, but played with words and is more entertaining.

You can even play poker style games that involve many more strategies and scoring options, such as;
“Word For Word” - plays similar to Texas Hold 'em.
“Keep Your Word” - plays similar to 7-Card Stud.
“Choose Your Words” - plays similar to 7-Card Draw.
“Hold Your Words” - plays similar to 7-Card No Draw.
“A Few Words” - plays similar to 7-Card No Peek.

In addition, you get "Your Words, Not Mine" which creates several more variations of game play, allowing you to play many of the games backwards! Rather than competing for high score, each player competes for low score by transferring their words / scores to other players."

The deck comes with 176 cards.

From the web page:
" Cool Factors:

Lay down the letters!
 Baffle your opponents!
 Keep yourself in the game!

Description:
Frazzed (formerly Baffle) is the word game where you try to lay out the letters of your own word while preventing everyone else from guessing your word, because if they do, you're out of the game. Meanwhile, you can eliminate your opponents by guessing their words."

There is a Letter Cards Deck with 275 cards, and a Word Cards Deck with 100 cards.

Game description from the publisher:

The fires of continent-spanning war engulf western Immoren, forging great leaders in a crucible of conflict. Bold commanders orchestrate grand strategies and daring battlefield tactics, their actions bringing glorious victory—or the despair of final defeat. Do you have the courage and cunning to lead your forces to ultimate triumph? Take command and muster the military might of an entire nation to conquer the Iron Kingdoms!

Warmachine: High Command is a deck-building card game for 2-4 players set in the steam-powered fantasy world of the Iron Kingdoms. Leverage your resources, rally your armies, and dominate your foes to set your banner above all of western Immoren!

This set can be combined with the following other core sets:

Hordes: High Command

Game description from the publisher:

Brutal conflict spreads across the wilds of western Immoren, fought by savage warriors and terrible beasts. Powerful warlords orchestrate grand strategies and daring battlefield tactics, their actions bringing glorious victory — or the despair of final defeat. Do you have the courage and cunning to guide your forces to ultimate triumph? Take command of the mightiest warriors and beasts to conquer the wilds of Immoren!

In Hordes: High Command, each player takes control of one faction of the Hordes world – Skorn, Circle of Orboros, Trollblods or Legion of Eveblight – leading whole armies of soldiers, Warlocks and mighty Warbeasts to great battles which will shake all of Immoren and change it forever. Each faction has individual decks with faction-specific warbeasts, units, and resources which assure different strategy and gameplay from the other factions. Additionally, before each game, players choose three of the five warlocks specific to their faction. This decision makes every game different and allows for multiple strategies. During the game, players play a whole season of War, trying to build up their strength, then capture strategic locations to earn victory points.

item.description:
Objective:
get most money within agreed time
 - acting by turns -
 
a classical Monopoly, taking place in Bavaria, Germany with all the well known activities like buying, trading..
typically 3-6 players, including banker 7

Darklands is a world in which you command the armies of man and beast that your ancestors once did for glory, power or simple survival.

What if dragons really flew and giants really walked the earth? What if berserkers actually were bear-men, man and bear joined together? What if all of the myths and legends we take for granted were real and our ancestors fought against - and with - creatures and beings and realms we thought were nothing more than the fantasies of our uncivilised selves?

Based in the Dark Ages in the year 650AD in Northwest Europe, Darklands is a Skirmish Wargame that allows you to field the men and mythological beasts of the time. This game will allow you to:
- Take command of Norse Trolls and Jötunn and conduct raids on the coast of Dark Age Britain.
- Lead the hosts of Baalor, the Evil Eye in the Ice, and the Fomoraic, a race of half men and beast along with hideous sea creatures under the thrall of Baalor in their quest to crush Dark Age Ireland.
- Defend Dark Age Wales with the Brythoniaid and their draconic allies.

The game will feature the following Kindreds (factions):
- Albainn (Picts) 
- Angelcynn (Angles)
- Atalantes (Classic Greeks from the mythical continent of Atlantis)
- Brythoniaid (Welsh Britons)
- Byzantii (Dark Age Romans)
- Érainn (Irish)
- Fomoraic (Fomorians)
- Khthones (Escaped slaves of the Atlantes and all are Reptilian Anthropomorphs such as Snakes, Crocodiles, Hydras and Basilisks)
- Norse (Vikings)
- Ysians (An alliance of Kernow and the mythical city of Ys)

With these additional, smaller Kindreds appearing as allies to the others:
- The Vras (Greedy ratmen allied with the Ysians)
- Infernii (Daemons from Dantes Divine Comedy allied with the Byzantii)

Some features of the gameplay:
- Individual alternate unit activation
- D10s based
- Inches are the primary measurement
- Game turns are called 'Hours'
- Will feature weather and time of day
- A big mechanic of the game is that all warriors large and small, when they are wounded, become weaker for the rest of the game.
- Bows will be able to shoot arrows the length of the table and beyond - but their shots loose power with increased range.
- Army Standards and Army Musicians important to game play and orders
- Plastic round bases with arcs of visibility pre-marked
- Dark Magic will be involved. Using it will come “at a price”

name.value: Night Eternal: A True Blood Card Game

item.description:
Game description from the publisher:

In ancient times, immortal vampires played games with people's lives and with real blood stakes. Now in card game form, no real blood will be spilled, but the strategy, tactics, and power-plays still abound. Based upon a game that exists in the True Blood universe, Night Eternal: The Game is a competitive card game of intrigue, power-plays and betrayal where vampires jockey for power, position and ultimate control of the rival factions: The Authority and The Monarchy.

Players must ante blood from their pools to both factions each turn of the game. Players build up their hands by acquiring cards from a powerful, but temperamental Immortals deck and a willing and able Agent deck. The cards that a player chooses to play will determine the faction to which he or she is loyal...for now. In turn order, each player plays out one card (face up) during each of three rounds each turn, so you never just how much power it will take to seize control of a faction each turn.

Players must pay attention to the cards their opponents are playing. It's more difficult to enable a powerful card's special ability if your opponents are playing weaker cards. Weaker card special abilities are easy to resolve, but weakness doesn't win the war. Special abilities might allow a player to steal blood from a faction or move it from one faction to another, so switching your loyalty to a new faction (by playing cards of that faction) might just throw off your opponents' best laid plans.

In the end, power still rules the day. At the end of each turn (after three rounds of card play), the cards are scored. The player with the highest value of Authority cards earns that faction's blood pool. The player with the highest value of Monarchy cards earns that faction's blood pool. The key to victory is to have more blood tokens than any other player when the first player dies...by running out
of blood.

item.description:
Players each have one or two pawns. Depending on a dice roll they chose which pawn to advance along the spiral. Pawns landing on or adjacent to their own colour advance forward or backward along the spiral, or move inward or outward. If you and on another pawn the other pawn moves backwards five spaces, but may then in turn trigger off backward, forward, inward or outward movements.

A quick, fun family game reminiscent to Clue (Cluedo), which offers some interesting tactical decisions.

Objective: gain most point by fixing squares
 - acting by turns -
During her/his turn each player places a (yellow) meeple on the board (a grid of 5x7 squares), filling one free corner of a square;
as soon as one (or more) square(s) is(are) fully occupied number(s) within is(are) added or subtracted (depending on colour) to/from your account.

The Exodus TCG is an extremely fast-paced card game, designed to play in an average of 5-10 minutes suitable for all ages and skill levels. It's the first trading card game in the world to feature mechanics that affect card rarity! There's no banlist, no rotation, and no reprints from set-to-set. Expansions offer new and interesting mechanics and themes without relying on power-creep.

A mass Exodus to the newborn planet Eeventide is occurring. As you venture from Earth to Eeventide, you become a Drifter, gaining the ability to fly and drift across a new world. Forge a special deck of cards from stardust, and battle other Drifters by summoning massive creatures to fight for you! Your very existence is bound to the planet by a mysterious contraption that glows with an ethereal light. You can join a faction or fight solo as you pave a path. 
The first three guilds have risen, Dragonis, Skyborn & the Order, each fighting over a planet that requires constant conflict in order to remain stable.


Players begin the game with 10 Life Points, which represent their will to battle. Each player takes turns playing by following the 5 Phases of a Turn:

 Draw Phase: Draw 3 cards from your Energy Deck and 3 cards from your Main Deck
 Energy Phase: Play your energy onto the field by stacking them into piles in any arrangement you'd like (maximum 3-energy per pile by default)
 Creature Phase: Summon as many creatures from your hand as you'd like by placing them on blank piles of energy
 Attack Phase: Attack your opponent's creatures using your own, or attack their Life Points directly if they have no creatures
 End Phase: Pass the turn to your opponent
 




Players win the game by using their creatures to attack their opponent's Life Points directly. Each energy behind a creature counts as 1 point of damage in a direct attack. Players can attack with as many creatures as they want during their turn, and use instant-speed Symmetry cards to make their creatures stronger or to drastically change circumstances during a duel. Symmetry cards are like quick-play instants that can be played literally at any time to interrupt gameplay (they can be used on your turn or your opponent's turn, on any phase)!

Energy cards are universal in function, so players can use any combination of cards. Decks can be constructed by following the one simple rule of limiting 2 copies of a card per deck (excluding energy).


(Set 1) Birth of Creation Harmonized Dragonis & Skyborn Starter Decks (Unlimited Edition) are now available, Premiere Edition is sold out,
(Set 2) Galaxy Tides (First Edition) Boosters are now available,
(Set 3) Crystal Forge Treeforge & Shardveil Competitive Decks (First Edition) are now available, released August 2017,
